Do you remember the name of your kindergarten teacher?I do,mine.Her name was Mrs White.I don't   [MASK]   much about what we learned in her class,but my mother once told me that we   used   to write a lot.And I would bring back what I   wrote   and she would look at it and see there were so many   mistakes   .But no red crrections .And always a star.Sometimes even a "Good!" would make my   heart   filled with happiness.But it   worried   my mother,so one day,she went to meet Mrs White and asked her shy she never   corrected   my mistakes.And she also asked why Mrs White   never   red-pencilled in the right spellings of words or   pointed out   grammatical errors.Mrs White said"The children are just beginning to get excited about using   words   ,about forming sentences.I don't want to prevent that   enthusiasm   with red ink.Spelling and grammar can   wait   .The wonder of words won't...".Maybe she din't say it exactly like that.And what my omther gaveme was the general idea of what she could   remember   .The rest I added in .Because I grew up   learning   to use words with loving cnfidence like that. Centuries ago, a group of people left India.No one really knows  [MASK]  . [SEP] why
Over time, they journeyed west to Europe, where most have  [MASK]  ever since. [SEP] lived

These people called themselves the Roma.[MASK]  Europeans, thinking they came from Egypt, called them "gypsies ( )
Many people think of gypsies as  wandering  groups of people. [SEP] But

But  Europeans, thinking they came from Egypt, called them "gypsies ( )
Many people think of gypsies as  [MASK]  groups of people. [SEP] wandering
They are associated with colorful clothing, fortune telling and music.But this is not the real  [MASK]  of Roma culture. [SEP] picture
In fact, not all Roma are  [MASK]  . [SEP] travelers
Those in Western Europe have historically moved from place to place.But others who  [MASK]  in Eastern Europe built homes and stayed in one place. [SEP] settled
Roma culture  [MASK]  among regions. [SEP] varies
But most speak both the language of the  [MASK]  people and their own language, Romany. [SEP] surrounding
For centuries, Roma practiced  [MASK]  trades. [SEP] traditional
Some were horse traders or musicians.Others made things out of metal or wood.But today, Roma may be found in any  [MASK]  . [SEP] profession
Each Roma settlement developed its own  [MASK]  style, combining local music with Roma traditions. [SEP] musical
These styles often sound  [MASK]  to the music of the surrounding culture. [SEP] similar
However, most Roma music  [MASK]  some characteristics, including the timing of the notes and the harmonies. [SEP] shares
Roma music has also affected the music of other  [MASK]  . [SEP] cultures
Roma influences have shaped European folk and classical music and even some American styles.Like people of many cultures, the Roma love to tell  [MASK]  . [SEP] stories
Their conversations often include brief references  [MASK]  tales that the entire settlement knows. [SEP] to
But they also tell long stories during the evenings or while working.Some stories are funny, others  pass down  Roma traditions.Over the years, the Roma have  [MASK]  many challenges. [SEP] faced

Their neighbors did not  [MASK]  them and even accused them of being thieves.Today, many face poverty, prejudice and other problems.Nevertheless, the Roma people are proud of their history and their rich culture. [SEP] accept

seemed in anexpansive(,) mood as we walked home from church together."Tommy," he said letting   my name  roll off his tongue.My
mind raced ahead of his words: A new bike?A part-time job?"There
comes a time in every boy's life when he must take on responsibilities."
"  [MASK]  ?"
I asked. [SEP] Responsibilities

"Yes.It's time you took a greater role in the household." Power tools?Boss my baby brother?"Starting today, I want you to do the dishes on   Sunday morning  so
your mother and I can work the crossword puzzle together."
"The dishes!?"
" Anything  [MASK]  with taking over the dishes, son?"
I didn't taste a bit of breakfast that morning. [SEP] wrong
My sister began to clear the table.My brother was   [MASK]  the last of the egg from his plate. [SEP] scratching

And then that ancient

position."
My brother and sister stopped cold. [SEP] generously

left but to  [MASK]  . [SEP] refuse

Over the past few decades, more and more countries have opened up the markets, increasingly transforming the world economy into one free-flowing global market.The question is:Is economic globalization  [MASK]  for all? [SEP] good
According to the World Bank, one of its chief supporters, economic globalization has helped reduce  [MASK]  in a large number of developing countries. [SEP] poverty

It quotes one study that shows increased wealth  [MASK]  to improved education and longer life in twenty-four developing countries as a result of integration of local economies into the world economy. [SEP] contributing
Home to some three billion people, these twenty-four countries have seen incomes  [MASK]  at an average rate of five percent--compared to two percent in developed countries. [SEP] increase
Those who  [MASK]  globalization claim that economies in developing countries will benefit from new opportunities for small and home-based businesses. [SEP] advocate
For instance  , small farmers in Brazil who produce nuts that would originally have sold only in  [MASK]  open-air markets can now promote their goods worldwide by the Internet. [SEP] local
Critics take a different view, believing that economic globalization is actually  [MASK]  the gap between the rich and poor. [SEP] widening

A study carried out by the U.N.-sponsored World Commission on the Social Dimension of Globalization shows that only a few developing countries have actually  [MASK]  from integration into the world economy and that the poor, the uneducated, unskilled workers, and native peoples have been left behind. [SEP] profited
[MASK]  , they maintain that globalization may eventually threaten emerging businesses. [SEP] Furthermore

For example, Indian craftsmen who currently seem to benefit from globalization because they are able to  [MASK]  their products may soon face fierce competition that could put them out of  business  . [SEP] export

For example, Indian craftsmen who currently seem to benefit from globalization because they are able to  export  their products may soon face fierce competition that could put them out of  [MASK]  . [SEP] business

When large-scale manufacturers start to produce the same goods, or when superstores like Wal-Mart move in, these small businesses will not be able to  keep up  and will be crowded out.One thing is certain about globalization--there is no  turning back  .Advances in technology combined with more open policies have already created an interconnected world.The  [MASK]  now is finding a way to create a kind of globalization that works for the benefit of all. I was working at a financial firm in New York City with a  [MASK]  boss that I admired very much.I went to my boss and  shared  with him that I wanted to start a company selling books on the Internet.He took me on a long walk in Central Park,listened  carefully  to me,and finally said,"That sounds like a really good idea,  but  it would be an even better idea for someone who didn't already have a good job."That logic made some  sense  to me,and he convinced me to think about it for 48 hours  before  making a final decision.Seen in that light,it really was a difficult  choice  ,but finally, I decided I had to give it a shot.I didn't think I'd regret  trying  and failing.And I suspected I would always be troubled by the decision not to try at a11.After much  consideration  ,I took the less  secure  path to follow my dream,and I'm  proud  of that Choice.For all of us,in the end,we are our choices. AIDS wasn't  something  we talked about in my country when I was growing up.From then on, I knew that this would be a family  secret  .My parents were not together anymore, and my dad lived alone.For a while, he could take care of himself.But when I was 12, his condition worsened.My father's  other  children lived far away, so it  fell  to me to look after him.We couldn't afford all the necessary medication for him, and  because  Dad was unable to work, I had no money for school supplies and often couldn't  even  buy food for dinner.I would sit  in class  feeling completely  lost  , the teacher's words muffled as I tried to figure out  how  I was going to manage. I didn't share my burden with anyone.I had seen how people reacted to AIDS.Kids  laughed at  classmates who had parents with the disease.And even adults could be cruel.When my father was moved to the hospital, the nurses would leave his food on the bedside table even though he was  [MASK]  weak to feed himself.I had known that he was going to die,  but  after so many years of keeping his condition a secret, I was completely unprepared when he reached his final days.Sad and  hopeless  , I  called  a woman at the non-profit National AIDS Support.That day, she  kept  me on the phone for hours.I was so lucky to find someone who cared.She saved my life. My mother lived in an old farm house in north Oregon,which was located far from any other neighbors.She lived with her elder brother and sisters.Since there were not enough rooms for them,her two sisters  [MASK]  the bigger bedroom downstairs,her brother in a room down the hall and she slept in the top room of the building.
